title: Mosese Rauluni
text:
Mosese Nasau Rauluni (born 27 June 1975 in <a href="Suva">Suva</a>, <a href="Fiji">Fiji</a>) is a retired <a href="Fiji">Fiji</a>an <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> footballer. He usually plays at scrum half, and played for <a href="Saracens%20F.C.">Saracens</a> in the <a href="Guinness%20Premiership">Guinness Premiership</a> in <a href="England">England</a>. He has played for <a href="Fiji%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Fiji</a>, including captaining them. He is the younger brother of <a href="Jacob%20Rauluni">Jacob Rauluni</a> and first cousin of <a href="Waisale%20Serevi">Waisale Serevi</a>.
Career.
Rauluni was brought up in <a href="Brisbane">Brisbane</a> and played his club rugby for Easts from 1995 to 2004. He represented the Australian U-19s in 1993–94. He made his test debut for Fiji on 1 November 1996 in a match against the <a href="New%20Zealand%20M%C4%81ori%20rugby%20union%20team">New Zealand Māori</a>. The following season he was capped another three times for Fiji, playing in test matches against <a href="Tonga%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Tonga</a>, the <a href="Cook%20Islands%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Cook Islands</a> and <a href="Samoa%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Samoa</a>. The following season he played in a Test against the <a href="Australia%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Wallabies</a>.
He returned to the international scene for Fiji in May 1999, playing against the <a href="United%20States%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">United States</a> and then playing subsequent matches against <a href="Spain%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Spain</a> and <a href="Italy%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Italy</a>. He was included in Fiji's <a href="1999%20Rugby%20World%20Cup">1999 Rugby World Cup</a> squad, and played in all four pool matches. After the World Cup, he earned another five caps during the subsequent season for Fiji. He played only one test in 2001, on 25 May against <a href="Tonga%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Tonga</a>.
In 2003 Rauluni played in a match against <a href="Tonga%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Tonga</a> and in fixtures against <a href="Argentina%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Argentina</a> and <a href="Chile%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Chile</a>. He was selected for Fiji's squad at the <a href="2003%20Rugby%20World%20Cup">2003 Rugby World Cup</a>. He represented Fiji in four matches at the World Cup.
In 2004 he was capped twice for Fiji in games against <a href="Samoa%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Samoa</a> and <a href="Tonga%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Tonga</a>; these two games were actually <a href="2007%20Rugby%20World%20Cup">2007 World Cup</a> qualifying matches, and Rauluni skippered Fiji on both occasions. In July of that year he was selected as part of the <a href="Pacific%20Islanders%20rugby%20union%20team">Pacific Islanders</a> side, which was a touring team composed of the best Fijian, Samoan and Tongan players. The Pacific Islanders played matches against <a href="South%20Africa%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">South Africa</a>, <a href="Australia%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Australia</a> and the <a href="New%20Zealand%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">All Blacks</a>. He was capped nine times during 2005. In May 2006 he re-signed with the Saracens until the 2007/08 season. He was a key to help Fiji to reach the quarterfinal at the 2007 RWC. Some regarded him as the half back of the tournament.
He was forced to retire due to injury in June 2010 and later, later being recruited by <a href="Sam%20Domoni">Sam Domoni</a>, the <a href="Fiji%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Flying Fijians</a> head coach, ahead of the <a href="2011%20Rugby%20World%20Cup">2011 Rugby World Cup</a>, which would see Rauluni coach the backs. In June 2010 he coached the Saracens academy side, with <a href="Kevin%20Sorrell">Kevin Sorrell</a>, before becoming head coach of <a href="Harrow%20School">Harrow School</a>, an English private school. He returned to Fiji in 2014, joining the new coaching set up under <a href="John%20McKee%20%28rugby%20union%29">John McKee</a> of which Rauluni and McKee guided Fiji to qualification to the <a href="2015%20Rugby%20World%20Cup">2015 Rugby World Cup</a>. He is now the Defensive and skills coach with the national team.
